DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Continue Marathon Coal Strike Negotiations
EDS: Top prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Bargainers for the United Mine Workers and the Pittston Co. continued marathon negotiations Saturday as they pushed for an end to a bitter strike that's idled coal miners in three states since April. The two sides returned to the table about 9 a.m. Saturday after meeting behind closed doors at a Washington hotel until about 2:30 a.m., said Herb Fishgold, an aide to mediator W.J. Usery. Saturday's daylong bargaining session was the fourth since Christmas. Both sides were under a gag order imposed by Usery and it was unclear whether the same kind of progress was made during the latest round of negotiations as was reported during the pre-Christmas meetings. Usery, a former labor secretary named by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole to mediate the coal talks, said last week he'd like to have a tentative settlement by New Year's Day for miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. At the UMW office in Castlewood, Va., District 28 President Jackie Stump said he had been telling striking miners, ``if it does happen it will be great, but just don't depend on it.'' Even if Pittston miners start off the year with a new contract, things won't be the same as before in the coalfields before the bitter dispute, Stump said. ``It's going to take a while, and maybe a long time ... for the wounds to heal,'' Stump said. Some 1,700 coal miners in the three states are on strike against Pittston. The union said the company's decision to end contributions to a United Mine Workers retirement and health plan and job security were the main issues. The miners had worked 14 months without a contract before the strike began April 5. The violence-marred walkout was prompted by Pittston's refusal to contribute to the UMW's industry-wide fund for miners' retirement and health plans for some 130,000 pensioners. Pittston, the nation's largest coal exporter, says it cannot afford the payments other U.S. coal companies make because it faces greater costs in sending coal abroad. Union leaders said other coal companies also would refuse to pay into the benefit plan if Pittston's attempt to stay out held up. The UMW has given each striker about $200 a week in benefits, and the union said it would give strikers a $1,250 Christmas bonus. The union is facing fines totaling $63.5 million for violating court orders limiting picketing and other strike activities. Pittston has hired replacement workers, but production has been well below pre-strike levels. The company reported its coal operations lost $3.6 million in the second quarter of 1989 and $9.8 million in the third quarter, compared with profits of $9 million and $7.4 million in the respective quarters of 1988.
